info.title: F5 Distributed Cloud Services API for ves.io.schema.infraprotect
info.description: APIs to get monitoring data for infraprotect.

get.description: RPC to get customer access and availability info.

401.description: Returned when operation is not authorized

403.description: Returned when there is no permission to access resource

404.description: Returned when resource is not found

409.description: Returned when operation on resource is conflicting with current value

429.description: Returned when operation has been rejected as it is happening too frequently

500.description: Returned when server encountered an error in processing API

503.description: Returned when service is unavailable temporarily

504.description: Returned when server timed out processing request

get.description: RPC to get details of an alert.

401.description: Returned when operation is not authorized

403.description: Returned when there is no permission to access resource

404.description: Returned when resource is not found

409.description: Returned when operation on resource is conflicting with current value

429.description: Returned when operation has been rejected as it is happening too frequently

500.description: Returned when server encountered an error in processing API

503.description: Returned when service is unavailable temporarily

504.description: Returned when server timed out processing request

parameters.description:
Namespace

x-example: "value"
This request is supported only in system namespace.

parameters.name: alert_id
parameters.description:
Alert ID

x-example: "12345"
ID of the alert we want to get details for.

post.description:
RPC to get a list of Alerts. Alerts are raised when an attack is detected by L3/L4 provider.
Alerts help to start investigate and mitigate any malicious or suspicious activate.

post.description:
Returns a list of events. Events are created when a high priority mitigation is started. Events then serve as a
one stop shop to review activities to mitigate a DDoS attack.

data_expected_ts.description:
if set then it indicates the date when we expect the customer to have data present

Example: ` "2021-01-01T00:00:00Z"`
data_expected_ts.title: Data expected

data_present.description: if true then the customer has some data available, otherwise no data available
data_present.title: Data present

enabled.description: if true then the customer has this feature enabled
enabled.title: Enabled

infraprotectAddAlertToEventRequest.description: Request to add an alert to event (link them together)
infraprotectAddAlertToEventRequest.title: Add Alert to Event

alert_id.description:
Alert to be link with an event

Example: ` "9ba097cf-35e3-4560-9c00-5a1a36b8f85b"`
alert_id.title: Alert ID

event_id.description:
Event to be link with an alert

Example: ` "9ba097cf-35e3-4560-9c00-5a1a36b8f85b"`
event_id.title: Event ID

namespace.description:
This request is supported only in system namespace.

Example: ` "value"`
namespace.title: Namespace

infraprotectAddAlertToEventResponse.description: Response to adding an alert to event
infraprotectAddAlertToEventResponse.title: Add Alert to Event

infraprotectAddEventDetailRequest.description: Request to add a single event detail to an event
infraprotectAddEventDetailRequest.title: Request to add event detail

attachments.description: All attachments on an event details
attachments.title: Attachments

description.description:
Description of the event detail

Example: ` "Actions taken..."`
description.title: Description

event_id.description:
Event ID we want to list the event details for.

Example: ` "8094c17b-80c1-429d-8b17-7232f0e2937c"`
event_id.title: Event ID

namespace.description:
This request is supported only in system namespace.

Example: ` "value"`
namespace.title: Namespace

time.description:
Time of the event detail
 Format: RFC3339

Example: ` "2021-01-01T00:00:00Z"`
time.title: Time

title.description:
Title of the event of the event detail

Example: ` "Actions taken so far"`
title.title: Title

infraprotectAddEventDetailResponse.description: Event detail as stored in the backend
infraprotectAddEventDetailResponse.title: Event detail as stored

bandwidth.description:
Bandwidth that triggered the alert in BPS.

Example: ` "10000000"`
bandwidth.title: Bandwidth

creator.description: Creator of the alert (or SOC if created manually)
creator.title: Creator

end_time.description:
End time of the alert. This is when the threshold was restored.

Example: ` "2021-01-01T00:00:00Z"`
end_time.title: End time

events.description: List of associated alerts. These alerts are normally manually associated.
events.title: Events

id.description:
ID of the alert used to uniquely identify it.

Example: ` "9ba097cf-35e3-4560-9c00-5a1a36b8f85b"`
id.title: Id

ip.description:
IP the alert is triggered for. This is the "protected" IP

Example: ` "127.0.0.1"`
ip.title: IP address

network_id.description: Network the alert is related to
network_id.title: Network ID

start_time.description:
Start time of the alert. This is when a threshold was exceeded.

Example: ` "2021-01-01T00:00:00Z"`
start_time.title: Start time

type.description:
Type of the alert, e.g. DoS host alert

Example: ` "DoS host alert"`
type.title: Alert type

infraprotectAlertPort.description: Single occurrence of a port in an alert
infraprotectAlertPort.title: Alert port

bytes.description:
Bytes received on the port.

Example: ` "12345"`
bytes.title: Bytes

destination.description: Destination flag - if rue then the port field is the destination of the alert.
destination.title: Destination

name.description:
Logical name of the port.

Example: ` "HTTPS"`
name.title: Name

number.description:
Port number involved in the alert.

Example: ` "8080"`
number.title: Port number

packets.description:
Packets received on the port.

Example: ` "12345"`
packets.title: packets

protocol.description:
Protocol used on the port.

Example: ` "UDP"`
protocol.title: Protocol

infraprotectAlertPrefix.description: Single occurrence of a prefix in an alert
infraprotectAlertPrefix.title: Alert prefix

cidr.description:
Cidr of the alert source

Example: ` "127.0.0.1/0"`
cidr.title: Cidr

destination.description: Destination flag - if rue then the Cidr field is the destination of the alert.
destination.title: Destination

num_bytes.description:
Bytes received on the Cidr.

Example: ` "12345"`
num_bytes.title: Bytes

num_packets.description:
Packets received on the Cidr.

Example: ` "12345"`
num_packets.title: Packets

infraprotectAlertSourceType.description:
Alert source type - helps the UI distinguish alerts coming from different sources

 - ALERT_SOURCE_TYPE_UNKNOWN: Unspecified source type
 - ALERT_SOURCE_TYPE_MITIGATED: Alert is sourced from a mitigated-type system
 - ALERT_SOURCE_TYPE_AUTOMITIGATED: Alert is sourced from an automitigated-type system
infraprotectAlertSourceType.title: Alert source type

infraprotectAttachment.description: Event attachment record (pcap, or any arbitrary file)
infraprotectAttachment.title: Event attachment

end_time.description:
End time as an RFC3339 string

Example: ` "2021-01-01T00:00:00Z"`
end_time.title: End time

gos_name.description:
Generic object storage name of the attachment

Example: ` "attachment_123"`
gos_name.title: GOS name

gos_version.description:
Generic object storage version of the attachment

Example: ` "v01-00-00-00"`
gos_version.title: GOS version

start_time.description:
Start time as an RFC3339 string

Example: ` "2021-01-01T00:00:00Z"`
start_time.title: Start time

infraprotectAttachmentType.description:
Attachment type - helps the UI to properly handle attachments as not all attachment cna be treated the same

 - ATTACHMENT_TYPE_UNKNOWN: Unspecified attachment
 - ATTACHMENT_TYPE_PCAP: Attachment is a PCAP file
 - ATTACHMENT_TYPE_BINARY: Attachment is a binary file
 - ATTACHMENT_TYPE_INVALID_PCAP: Attachment type indicated as, however the file format is different
 - ATTACHMENT_TYPE_OTHER: Attachment is other than above
infraprotectAttachmentType.title: Attachment type

infraprotectBGPPeerStatusItem.description: Routed DDoS BGP peer status data specific to a given router/peer combination
infraprotectBGPPeerStatusItem.title: BGP Peer Status Item

asn.description:
Autonomous System Number for BGP peer

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.uint32.gte: 1
asn.title: ASN

infraprotectBGPPeerStatusRequest.description: Request to get routed DDoS BGP peer status information
infraprotectBGPPeerStatusRequest.title: BGP Peer Status Request

time.description:
Timestamp at which the snapshot of the bgp peer status data should be fetched.
 Format: unix_timestamp|rfc 3339

 Optional: If not specified, then the end_time will be evaluated  to <current time>

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.string.query_time: true
time.title: Time

infraprotectBGPPeerStatusResponse.description: Routed DDoS BGP peer status response data
infraprotectBGPPeerStatusResponse.title: BGP Peer Status Response

items.description: BGP Peer Status Items contains routed DDoS BGP peer status data for each router/peer combination
items.title: BGP Peer Status Items

infraprotectBgpPeerSessionState.description:
Status of BGP connection to this Peer

Connection state is Idle
Connection state is Connecting
Connection state is Active
Connection state is Open Sent
Connection state is Open Confirm
Connection state is Established
infraprotectBgpPeerSessionState.title: BGP Peer Session State

infraprotectCustomerAccessResponse.description: Infraprotect and L3/L4 ddos accessibility and availability flags response.
infraprotectCustomerAccessResponse.title: Response to get customer access flags

infraprotectDeviceLocation.description: Location of a network device (aka router) where DDoS transit tunnels are provisioned
infraprotectDeviceLocation.title: Device Location

name.description:
Device location name

Example: ` "ves-io-seattle"`

Required: YES

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.message.required: true
  ves.io.schema.rules.string.max_len: 256
name.title: Location Name

infraprotectEditEventDetailRequest.description: Request to update a single event detail
infraprotectEditEventDetailRequest.title: Request to update event detail

attachments.description: All attachments on an event details, missing will be removed, extras will be added
attachments.title: Attachments

description.description:
Description of the event detail

Example: ` "Actions taken..."`
description.title: Description

infraprotectTransitUsageData.title: Transit Usage Data

infraprotectTransitUsageRequest.description: Request to get transit usage data
infraprotectTransitUsageRequest.title: Transit Usage Request

end_time.description:
end time of metric collection from which data will be considered to build graph.
 Format: unix_timestamp|rfc 3339

 Optional: If not specified, then the end_time will be evaluated to start_time+10m
           If start_time is not specified, then the end_time will be evaluated to <current time>

Example: ` "1570197600"`

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.string.query_time: true
end_time.title: End time

field_selector.description:
Select fields to be returned in the response.
 One or more fields in {IN_THROUGHPUT_BYTES, IN_THROUGHPUT_PACKETS, OUT_THROUGHPUT_BYTES, OUT_THROUGHPUT_PACKETS} can be specified.

Required: YES

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.message.required: true
  ves.io.schema.rules.repeated.max_items: 8
  ves.io.schema.rules.repeated.min_items: 1
  ves.io.schema.rules.repeated.unique: true
field_selector.title: Field Selector

filter.description:
filter is used to specify the list of matchers
 syntax for filter := {[<matcher>]}
 <matcher> := <label><operator>"<value>"
   <label> := string
     One or more labels defined in MetricLabel {POP, DEVICE, INTERFACE} can be specified in the filter.
   <value> := string
   <operator> := ["="|"!="|"=~"|"!~"]
     =  : equal to
     != : not equal to
     =~ : regex match
     !~ : not regex match

 Optional: If not specified, metric will be aggregated based on the group_by labels. 

Example: ` "{POP=\"pop-1\"}"`
filter.title: Label Filter

group_by.description: Aggregate data by zero or more labels {POP, DEVICE, INTERFACE}
group_by.title: Group by

range.description:
range decides how far to go back in time to fetch values for each step.
 For example, if the range is 5m, then for step t1, query will be evaluated for t1-5m and for
 t2, query will be evaluated for t2-5m and so on.
 Format: [0-9][smhd], where s - seconds, m - minutes, h - hours, d - days

 Note: For non-timeseries query, i.e., for step=end_time-start_time, range should be set to end_time-start_time

 Optional: If not specified, range is set to 5m

Example: ` "10m"`

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.string.time_interval: true
range.title: Range

start_time.description:
start time of metric collection from which data will be considered to build graph.
 Format: unix_timestamp|rfc 3339

 Optional: If not specified, then the start_time will be evaluated to end_time-10m
           If end_time is not specified, then the start_time will be evaluated to <current time>-10m

Example: ` "1570194000"`

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.string.query_time: true
start_time.title: Start time

step.description:
step is the resolution width, which determines the number of the data points [x-axis (time)] to be returned in the response.
 The timestamps in the response will be t1=start_time, t2=t1+step, ... tn=tn-1+step, where tn <= end_time.
 Format: [0-9][smhd], where s - seconds, m - minutes, h - hours, d - days

 Optional: If not specified, then step size is evaluated to <end_time - start_time>

Example: ` "5m"`

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.string.query_step: true
step.title: Step

data.description: Data contains time-series Transit Usage data
data.title: Data

step.description:
Actual step size used in the response. It could be higher than the requested step due to metric rollups and the query duration.
 Format: [0-9][smhd], where s - seconds, m - minutes, h - hours, d - days

Example: ` "30m"`

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.string.time_interval: true
step.title: step

key.description:

 "name" is the label name defined in "TransitUsageLabel"
key.title: Key

type_url.description:
A URL/resource name that uniquely identifies the type of the serialized
protocol buffer message. This string must contain at least
one "/" character. The last segment of the URL's path must represent
the fully qualified name of the type (as in
`path/google.protobuf.Duration`). The name should be in a canonical form
(e.g., leading "." is not accepted).

In practice, teams usually precompile into the binary all types that they
expect it to use in the context of Any. However, for URLs which use the
scheme `http`, `https`, or no scheme, one can optionally set up a type
server that maps type URLs to message definitions as follows:

* If no scheme is provided, `https` is assumed.
* An HTTP GET on the URL must yield a [google.protobuf.Type][]
  value in binary format, or produce an error.
* Applications are allowed to cache lookup results based on the
  URL, or have them precompiled into a binary to avoid any
  lookup. Therefore, binary compatibility needs to be preserved
  on changes to types. (Use versioned type names to manage
  breaking changes.)

Note: this functionality is not currently available in the official
protobuf release, and it is not used for type URLs beginning with
type.googleapis.com.

Schemes other than `http`, `https` (or the empty scheme) might be
used with implementation specific semantics.

value.description: Must be a valid serialized protocol buffer of the above specified type.

schemaEmpty.description: This can be used for messages where no values are needed
schemaEmpty.title: Empty

schemaIpAddressType.description: IP Address used to specify an IPv4 or IPv6 address
schemaIpAddressType.title: IP Address

addr.description:
IPv4 Address in string form with dot-decimal notation

Example: ` "192.168.1.1"`

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.string.ipv4: true
addr.title: IPv4 Address

schemaIpv6AddressType.description: IPv6 Address specified as hexadecimal numbers separated by ':'
schemaIpv6AddressType.title: IPv6 Address

addr.description:
IPv6 Address in form of string. IPv6 address must be specified as hexadecimal numbers separated by ':'
 The address can be compacted by suppressing zeros
 e.g. '2001:db8:0:0:0:0:2:1' becomes '2001:db8::2:1' or '2001:db8:0:0:0:2:0:0' becomes '2001:db8::2::'

Example: ` "2001:db8:0:0:0:0:2:1"`

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.string.ipv6: true
addr.title: IPv6 Address

schemaMetricValue.description: Metric data contains timestamp and the value.
schemaMetricValue.title: Metric Value

schemaPrefixListType.description:
List of IP Address prefixes. Prefix must contain both prefix and prefix-length
The list can contain mix of both IPv4 and IPv6 prefixes
schemaPrefixListType.title: IP Prefix List

prefix.description:
IP Address prefix in string format. String must contain both prefix and prefix-length

Example: ` "[192.168.1.0/24, 192.168.2.0/24]""`

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.repeated.items.string.ipv4_prefix: true
  ves.io.schema.rules.repeated.max_items: 256
prefix.title: Prefix

This type establishes a direct reference from one object(the referrer) to another(the referred).
Such a reference is in form of tenant/namespace/name

When a configuration object(e.g. virtual_host) refers to another(e.g route)

Example: ` "contacts-route"`
